1.text: These are the words of King Lemuel—the burden that his mother taught him:

2.text: What shall I say, O my son? What, O son of my womb? What, O son of my vows?

3.text: Do not spend your strength on women or your vigor on those who ruin kings.

4.text: It is not for kings, O Lemuel, it is not for kings to drink wine, or for rulers to crave strong drink,

5.text: lest they drink and forget what is decreed, depriving all the oppressed of justice.

6.text: Give strong drink to one who is perishing, and wine to the bitter in soul.

7.text: Let him drink and forget his poverty, and remember his misery no more.

8.text: Open your mouth for those with no voice, for the cause of all the dispossessed.

9.text: Open your mouth, judge righteously, and defend the cause of the poor and needy.

10.text: A wife of noble character, who can find? She is far more precious than rubies.

11.text: The heart of her husband trusts in her, and he lacks nothing of value.

12.text: She brings him good and not harm all the days of her life.

13.text: She selects wool and flax and works with eager hands.

14.text: She is like the merchant ships, bringing her food from afar.

15.text: She rises while it is still night to provide food for her household and portions for her maidservants.

16.text: She appraises a field and buys it; from her earnings she plants a vineyard.

17.text: She girds herself with strength and shows that her arms are strong.

18.text: She sees that her gain is good, and her lamp is not extinguished at night.

19.text: She stretches out her hands to the distaff and grasps the spindle with her fingers.

20.text: She opens her arms to the poor and reaches out her hands to the needy.

21.text: When it snows, she has no fear for her household, for they are all clothed in scarlet.

22.text: She makes coverings for her bed; her clothing is fine linen and purple.

23.text: Her husband is known at the city gates, where he sits among the elders of the land.

24.text: She makes linen garments and sells them; she delivers sashes to the merchants.

25.text: Strength and honor are her clothing, and she can laugh at the days to come.

26.text: She opens her mouth with wisdom, and faithful instruction is on her tongue.

27.text: She watches over the affairs of her household and does not eat the bread of idleness.

28.text: Her children rise up and call her blessed; her husband praises her as well:

29.text: “Many daughters have done noble things, but you surpass them all!”

30.text: Charm is deceptive and beauty is fleeting, but a woman who fears the LORD is to be praised.

31.text: Give her the fruit of her hands, and let her works praise her at the gates.
